required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Safety of Cultured Allogeneic Adult Umbilical Cord Derived Mesenchymal Stem Cell Intravenous Infusion for MS
clinical_study.official_title: Safety of Cultured Allogeneic Adult Umbilical Cord Derived Mesenchymal Stem Cell Intravenous Infusion for the Treatment of Multiple Sclerosis

lead_sponsor.agency: The Foundation for Orthopaedics and Regenerative Medicine

clinical_study.source: The Foundation for Orthopaedics and Regenerative Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: This trial will study the safety and efficacy of intravenous infusion of cultured allogeneic adult umbilical cord derived mesenchymal stem cells for the treatment of multiple sclerosis

detailed_description.textblock: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) can be a devastating disease. There is evidence that mesenchymal stem cell treatment is safe and efficacious for the treatment of MS. Patients with MS will receive a single intravenous infusion of cultured allogeneic adult umbilical cord derived mesenchymal stem cells. The dose for the infusion will be 100 million cells. Patients will be evaluated within one month pre treatment and at 1, 6, 12, 24, 36, and 48 months post treatment for safety and efficacy.

primary_outcome.description: Clinical monitoring of possible adverse events or complications

secondary_outcome.measure: Efficacy: Kurtzke Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS)
secondary_outcome.description: EDSS is a scale to evaluate the function of the central nervous system. It will be completed for each follow up point

arm_group.description: Single intravenous infusion of 100 million cells

intervention.description: cultured allogeneic adult umbilical cord derived mesenchymal stem cells

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of Multiple Sclerosis
- Understanding and willingness to sign a written informed consent document
Exclusion Criteria:
- Active infection
- Active cancer
- Chronic multisystem organ failure
- Pregnancy
- Clinically significant abnormalities on pre-treatment laboratory evaluation
- Medical condition that would (based on the opinion of the investigator) compromise patient's safety.
- Continued drug abuse
- Pre-menopausal women not using contraception
- Previous organ transplant
- Hypersensitivity to sulfur

overall_official.affiliation: The Foundation for Orthopaedics and Regenerative Medicine
